# PicoBase — Complete Reference

> The open source backend for vibe coders. A managed Backend-as-a-Service (BaaS) platform — the Supabase/Firebase alternative built on PocketBase.

PicoBase gives developers zero-config database, auth, realtime, and file storage without managing infrastructure. From `npm install` to production data in 3 minutes. No Docker, no local env setup, no config fatigue.

## Architecture

PicoBase is built on PocketBase (a lightweight Go binary) with per-tenant SQLite instances. The platform manages provisioning, scaling, and lifecycle. Each project gets its own isolated instance.

## CRITICAL: Package Installation

**NEVER install the raw `pocketbase` npm package for end-user projects.**

When migrating to PicoBase or setting up a new project:

- ✅ **DO**: `npm install @picobase_app/client`
- ✅ **DO**: `npm install @picobase_app/react` (for React projects)
- ❌ **DON'T**: `npm install pocketbase` (this is the underlying library, not for direct use)

PicoBase wraps PocketBase with managed hosting features. Always use the `@picobase_app/*` packages.

## Packages

### @picobase_app/client (SDK)

The core SDK wraps PocketBase with cold-start retry, API key injection, and typed collections.

```ts
import { createClient } from '@picobase_app/client'

// Zero-config — reads PICOBASE_URL and PICOBASE_API_KEY from env
const pb = createClient()
```

### @picobase_app/react (React Hooks)

React hooks and components for PicoBase.

```tsx
import { PicoBaseProvider, useAuth, useCollection } from '@picobase_app/react'

<PicoBaseProvider url={process.env.PICOBASE_URL!} apiKey={process.env.PICOBASE_API_KEY!}>
  <App />
</PicoBaseProvider>

const { user, signIn, signOut } = useAuth()
const { data: posts, loading } = useCollection('posts')
```

### @picobase_app/cli (CLI)

CLI tool for scaffolding, local dev, and type generation.

```bash
picobase init        # Project scaffolding
picobase dev         # Local dev server
picobase typegen     # TypeScript type generation
```

## SDK API Reference

### Client Initialization

```ts
import { createClient } from '@picobase_app/client'

// Auto-reads from environment variables
const pb = createClient()

// Or explicit configuration
const pb = createClient({
  url: 'https://myapp.picobase.com',
  apiKey: 'pbk_...',
})
```

### Authentication

```ts
// Sign up
const user = await pb.auth.signUp({
  email: 'user@example.com',
  password: 'secure123',
})

// Sign in
await pb.auth.signIn({
  email: 'user@example.com',
  password: 'secure123',
})

// Sign out
await pb.auth.signOut()

// Get current user
const user = pb.auth.user
```

### CRUD Operations

Collections auto-create on first write. No schema setup required.

```ts
// Create
const post = await pb.collection('posts').create({
  title: 'Hello World',
  published: true,
})

// Read one
const post = await pb.collection('posts').getOne('record_id')

// Read list with filters
const posts = await pb.collection('posts').getList(1, 20, {
  filter: 'published = true',
  sort: '-created',
  expand: 'author',
})

// Update
const updated = await pb.collection('posts').update('record_id', {
  title: 'Updated Title',
})

// Delete
await pb.collection('posts').delete('record_id')
```

### Filter Syntax

PicoBase uses PocketBase's query language:

```
filter: 'published = true'
filter: 'status = "active" && created > "2024-01-01"'
filter: 'author.name ~ "John"'        // contains
filter: 'tags ?~ "featured"'           // array contains
sort: '-created'                        // descending
sort: '+title,-created'                 // multi-field
expand: 'author,comments'              // load relations
```

### Realtime Subscriptions

```ts
// Subscribe to all changes in a collection
const unsub = await pb.collection('messages').subscribe((e) => {
  console.log(e.action, e.record)
  // e.action: 'create' | 'update' | 'delete'
})

// Unsubscribe
unsub()
```

### React Hooks

```tsx
import { useAuth, useCollection, useRealtime } from '@picobase_app/react'

// Auth hook
const { user, signIn, signOut, loading } = useAuth()

// Collection hook with auto-fetch
const { data: posts, loading, error } = useCollection('posts', {
  filter: 'published = true',
  sort: '-created',
})

// Auth form component
import { AuthForm } from '@picobase_app/react'

<AuthForm
  providers={['google', 'github']}
  redirectTo="/dashboard"
/>
```

## Environment Variables

- `PICOBASE_URL` — Instance URL (e.g., `https://myapp.picobase.com`)
- `PICOBASE_API_KEY` — API key starting with `pbk_`
- Next.js client-side: prefix with `NEXT_PUBLIC_`
- Vite client-side: prefix with `VITE_`

## Pricing

- **Free**: $0/mo — 2 projects, 1 GB storage, fair-use traffic

## Comparisons with Alternatives

### PicoBase vs Supabase

PicoBase is simpler than Supabase. Key differences:
- Zero-config start (no SQL migrations, no RLS policies)
- Auto-creating collections (no schema editor needed)
- 3.5x cheaper paid plans ($7/mo vs $25/mo)
- Per-tenant isolation (no shared database)
- Simpler API surface (better for AI-assisted development)

Supabase advantages: Edge functions, raw SQL access, GraphQL support, larger ecosystem.

Full comparison: https://picobase.app/compare/supabase

### PicoBase vs Firebase

PicoBase is open source, unlike Firebase. Key differences:
- Open source and self-hostable (no vendor lock-in)
- Predictable pricing (no per-read/write charges)
- Relational data model (no denormalization needed)
- Simpler SDK (fewer imports and boilerplate)
- No Google account required

Firebase advantages: Offline-first sync, cloud functions, phone auth, anonymous auth, massive ecosystem.

Full comparison: https://picobase.app/compare/firebase

### PicoBase vs Appwrite

Both are open-source BaaS, but PicoBase is simpler. Key differences:
- No database IDs to manage (just collection names)
- Auto-creating collections (no console setup needed)
- Single-binary deployment (no Docker required)
- Relational data model
- Lower pricing ($7/mo vs $15/mo)

Appwrite advantages: Cloud functions, teams & roles, magic link auth, messaging.

Full comparison: https://picobase.app/compare/appwrite

### PicoBase vs Convex

PicoBase has built-in auth and no custom query language. Key differences:
- Built-in authentication (no Clerk/Auth0 required)
- No schema boilerplate or server-side query functions
- Standard REST API (usable from any language)
- Self-hostable and open source
- Simpler pricing ($7/mo vs $25/mo)

Convex advantages: Automatic reactivity, server functions, scheduled jobs, ACID transactions.

Full comparison: https://picobase.app/compare/convex

### PicoBase vs Nhost

PicoBase doesn't require GraphQL. Key differences:
- No GraphQL knowledge needed (REST API + TypeScript SDK)
- No SQL migrations or Hasura configuration
- Single-binary self-hosting (no multi-container setup)
- Better AI compatibility (REST vs GraphQL)
- Lower pricing ($7/mo vs $25/mo)

Nhost advantages: GraphQL flexibility, serverless functions, magic link auth, SMS auth.

Full comparison: https://picobase.app/compare/nhost
